awd_abstract_narration:
The manipulation of small particles with light has enabled many applications in bioengineering and nanotechnology, including the trapping and accurate positioning of molecules, cells, and micro/nano-objects. These applications rely on the optical forces induced on the particles when they are illuminated by light. Since the strength of such forces is usually weak, laser beams with very high power are required to effectively control the position and motion of the particles. Recently, optical forces acting at the nano-scale have been enhanced by locating the particles near metallic surfaces, such as gold or silver, that support certain types of electromagnetic (EM) waves. It has been shown that the strength of the induced forces strongly depends on how confined these EM waves are. This project aims to achieve giant optical forces by replacing these metallic surfaces with engineered hyperbolic metasurfaces, which are advanced composite surfaces able to support extremely confined EM waves. The resulting devices will be able to route nanoparticles with very high accuracy using low-power laser beams. The educational and outreach efforts will focus on engaging Hispanic students, ranging from K-12 to college, in science, technology, engineering and math. Specifically, several undergraduate students will actively participate in the proposed research, providing them a path towards graduate school. K-12 activities include the participation in the California State Summer School for Mathematics and Science, as well as a set of talks on Hispanic schools in the Sacramento area. 

Technical description 
This project aims to theoretically model, numerically simulate and optimize, and experimentally realize and characterize a novel class of hyperbolic nano-optical tweezers with engineered near-fields able to generate giant optical forces several orders of magnitude larger than those attainable in isotropic, plasmonic surfaces. The proposed devices are based on combining the photonic spin Hall effect with ultra-confined surface plasmon polaritons in hyperbolic and anisotropic ultrathin metasurfaces. Rooted in this concept, the project objectives are to (i) reveal the fundamental limits and maximum strength of optical forces that can be attained by engineering the near-field of extremely anisotropic films; (ii) analyze and design realistic hyperbolic tweezers with near-optimal performance able to realize functionalities such as sub-diffractive nanoparticle positioning, optical trapping and binding; and (iii) fabricate and characterize hyperbolic nano-optical tweezers made of nanostructured silver. The resulting broadband devices will (i) provide attractive and repulsive forces of unprecedented strength at the nanoscale; (ii) reduce the intensity of required laser beams, thus avoiding damage to the particles due to photoheating; and (iii) enhance the local density of states, thus boosting the Raman spectroscopy and photoluminescence of trapped particles; and they have the potential to be transformative in the manipulation, trapping, assembly, and characterization of individual and multiple nanostructures, force measurement, and biological systems. The technical program will be combined with a number of outreach and educational activities aimed at integrating plasmonic tweezers into undergraduate/graduate education, with strong emphasis on the underrepresented Hispanic community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of this project was to analyze, design, fabricate, and characterize nano-optical tweezers based on hyperbolic metasurfaces. The idea relies on exploiting highly confined surface plasmons to enhance optical forces exerted on nanoparticles, and can have significant impact and application in biology, physics, medicine, and related fields. The first part of the project was devoted to developing a theoretical framework able to model giant recoil forces. To this purpose, an anisotropic Green's function formalism was proposed and combined with Lorentz's forces acting on very small particles (i.e., within the so-called Rayleigh limit). The proposed theory has been validated using numerical simulations and has led to a new understanding of the giant recoil forces that arise on nanoparticles located near hyperbolic metasurfaces. These forces were then proposed to construct nano-optical tweezers using low-power Gaussian beams. Next, the theoretical framework was extended to consider lateral recoil forces over nonreciprocal surfaces, such as drift-biased graphene or magneto-optic materials. This theory led to compact, analytical expressions that directly link the modes supported by the platform with the strength and properties of the forces acting on the nanoparticles. Such strong forces are useful to construct tunable optical traps that can be controlled with sub-wavelength resolution by modifying the external bias.

On the experimental front, the project got delayed due to the COVID outbreak. Despite several challenges, hyperbolic metamaterials were fabricated and characterized at the UC Davis cleanroom. These structures were applied to (i) enhance Raman signals on biological particles; and (ii) characterize the dynamic response of single molecules, including electrical, mechanical, and Raman components. Measured results confirm a very significant enhancement of the collected Raman signals due to the strong, localized fields found in hyperbolic media. In the last part of the project, vertical and lateral recoil forces were measured using an atomic force microscope. Measured data confirm that the displacements experienced by the nanotip are significantly enhanced when it is located over hyperbolic media versus the ones found when other materials such as metals and dielectric are employed. These promising results constitute the first experimental evidence of recoil forces over plasmonic media. 

Hyperbolic nano-optical tweezers will open unexplored possibilities to efficiently trap, manipulate, and characterize using Raman spectroscopy a wide variety of particles, including cells, molecules, proteins, and biocomponents, with broad and far-reaching technological applications. On the educational front, this project has provided multidisciplinary training to graduate and undergraduate students on a variety of scientific areas such as optical tweezers, metasurfaces, materials synthesis, device fabrication and characterization, and applied electromagnetics. Specifically, one student has already graduated with a PhD degree whereas another two graduate students at the PhD and MS level are finalizing their programs. Additionally, this program was able to attract and train a Hispanic MS student that was involved in the experimental characterization of optical recoil forces. Dissemination activities included the publication of several peer-review papers and the delivery of various talks at international conferences. The PI was involved with the LEADR (Leadership in Engineering Advancement, Diversity and Retention) program in UC Davis as well as in the Hispanic Association to promote STEM among first generation and Hispanic students.
